# 5 Proofs
### 5.1 Proof of Lemma 2.1

Proof. We now restrict $\mathcal{P}$ to be the set of smooth probability density functions

$$
\mathcal{P}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right):=\left\{p \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right): \int p(x) d x=1, p \geq 0\right\}
$$

whose tangent space is given by ${ }^{1}$

$$
T_{p} \mathcal{P}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)=\left\{\sigma \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right): \int \sigma(x) d x=0\right\}
$$

We start by computing the Fréchet derivative of (2.8) at $p$ : Set $\varepsilon>0$ and $q \in \mathcal{M}$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\mathcal{F}(q+\varepsilon \tilde{q})-\mathcal{F}(q)}{\varepsilon} & =-\iint f(x, z) \frac{(q(x)+\varepsilon \tilde{q}(x))(q(z)+\varepsilon \tilde{q}(z))-q(x) q(z)}{2 \varepsilon} \mathrm{~d} z \mathrm{~d} x \\
& =-\frac{1}{2} \iint f(x, z)[q(x) \tilde{q}(z)+q(z) \tilde{q}(x)+\varepsilon \tilde{q}(x) \tilde{q}(z)] \mathrm{d} z \mathrm{~d} x
\end{aligned}
$$

This means that, because $f$ is symmetric in its components,

$$
D_{q} \mathcal{F}[\tilde{q}]=-\iint f(x, z) q(z) \tilde{q}(x) \mathrm{d} z \mathrm{~d} x=-\int \pi_{q}(x) \tilde{q}(x) \mathrm{d} x=-\left\langle\pi_{q}, \tilde{q}\right\rangle
$$

which shows that

$$
\mathcal{F}^{\prime}(p)=-\pi_{p}
$$

(this is to be understood as a linear operator). For the dissipation mechanism, consider the Fisher-Rao metric defined as

$$
\begin{aligned}
g_{p}^{F R}\left(\sigma_{1}, \sigma_{2}\right) & =\int \frac{\sigma_{1}}{p(x)} \frac{\sigma_{2}}{p(x)} \mathrm{d} p(x)=\int \sigma_{1} \frac{\sigma_{2}}{p(x)} \mathrm{d} x \\
& \equiv \int \sigma_{1} \frac{\sigma_{2}}{p(x)} \mathrm{d} x-\int \sigma_{1} d x \cdot \int \sigma_{2} \mathrm{~d} x
\end{aligned}
$$

since $\sigma \in T_{p} \mathcal{P}$ satisfies $\int \sigma d x=0$. Its corresponding isomorphism/dual action $\mathcal{G}^{F R}(p): T_{p} \mathcal{P} \rightarrow T_{p}^{*} \mathcal{P}$ is given (by inspection) as

$$
\mathcal{G}^{F R}(p) \sigma=\frac{\sigma}{p}-\int \sigma d x
$$

The inverse mapping is given by

$$
\mathcal{G}^{F R}(p)^{-1} \Phi=\left(\Phi-\int \Phi p(x) d x\right) p
$$

Straightforwardly, we have

$$
-\mathcal{G}^{F R}(p)^{-1} \mathcal{F}^{\prime}(p)=\left(\pi_{p}(x)-\int \pi_{p}(x) p(x) d x\right) p(x)
$$

which yields the right-hand side of the replicator equation.

[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ Actually, if $p$ has a non-trivial support (e.g., there is an interval on which $p$ vanishes), then the tangent space needs to be replaced by a tangent cone $T_{p} \mathcal{P}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)=\left\{\sigma \in C_{\varepsilon}^{\infty}(\operatorname{supp}(p)): \int \sigma(x) d x=0\right\}$, see [MS18], but we forgo the technical details here.

# 5.2 Proof of Lemma 3.1 

Proof. The result follows from a simple re-arrangement of (3.5). Throughout, we use the shorthand notation $y_{t}:=\frac{d Z_{t}^{d}}{d t}$ and recall that $\|v(x)\|_{\Xi}^{2}:=v(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} v(x)$ for vector valued functions $v(x): \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Firstly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}_{z \sim \rho_{t}}\left[f_{t}(x, z)\right]-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}\left[f_{t}\right] & =\int\left(-\frac{r}{2}\left\|h(x)-y_{t}\right\|_{\Xi}^{2}+s\left\langle h(x)-y_{t}, h(z)-y_{t}\right\rangle_{\Xi}\right) \rho_{t}(z) d z \\
& -\iint\left(-\frac{r}{2}\left\|h(x)-y_{t}\right\|_{\Xi}^{2}+s\left\langle h(x)-y_{t}, h(z)-y_{t}\right\rangle_{\Xi}\right) \rho_{t}(x) \rho_{t}(z) d x d z \\
& =-\frac{r}{2}\left(\left\|h(x)-y_{t}\right\|_{\Xi}^{2}-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}\left[\left\|h-y_{t}\right\|_{\Xi}^{2}\right]\right)+s\left\langle h(x)-y_{t}, \mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[h]-y_{t}\right\rangle_{\Xi}-s\left\|\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[h]-y_{t}\right\|_{\Xi}^{2} \\
& =: I_{1}(x)+s I_{2}(x)+s I_{3}(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

For the first term, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{1}(x) & =-\frac{r}{2}\left(h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h(x)-h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} y_{t}-y_{t}^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h(x)-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}\left[h^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\right]+\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}\left[h^{\top}\right] \Xi^{-1} y_{t}+y_{t}^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[h]\right) \\
& =-\frac{r}{2}\left(h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h(x)-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}\left[h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h(x)\right]\right)+r\left(h(x)-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[h]\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} y_{t}
\end{aligned}
$$

For the remaining terms, we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{2}(x)+I_{3}(x) & =\left\langle h-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[h], \mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[h]-y_{t}\right\rangle_{\Xi} \\
& =-\frac{1}{2}\left\|h-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[h]\right\|_{\Xi}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} \mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}\left[h^{\top}\right] \Xi^{-1} \mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[h]+\frac{1}{2} h^{T} \Xi^{-1} h-\frac{1}{2} \mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}\left[h^{T} \Xi^{-1} h\right] \\
& +\frac{1}{2} \mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}\left[h^{T} \Xi^{-1} h\right]-\left(h-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[h]\right)^{T} \Xi^{-1} y_{t} \\
& =-\frac{1}{2}\left\|h-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[h]\right\|_{\Xi}^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}\left[h^{T} \Xi^{-1} h\right]-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}\left[h^{\top}\right] \Xi^{-1} \mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[h]\right) \\
& +\frac{1}{2}\left(h^{T} \Xi^{-1} h-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}\left[h^{T} \Xi^{-1} h\right]\right)-\left(h-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[h]\right)^{T} \Xi^{-1} y_{t}
\end{aligned}
$$

Combining yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{1}(x)+s I_{2}(x)+s I_{3}(x) & =-\frac{1}{2}(r-s)\left(h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h(x)-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}\left[h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h(x)\right]\right)+(r-s)\left(h(x)-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[h]\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} y_{t} \\
& -\frac{s}{2}\left\|h-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[h]\right\|_{\Xi}^{2}+\frac{s}{2}\left(\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}\left[h^{T} \Xi^{-1} h\right]-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}\left[h^{\top}\right] \Xi^{-1} \mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[h]\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting the above into (3.5) yields (3.6).

### 5.3 Proof of Theorem 3.1

Proof. Start with the reformulation of (3.5) as derived in Lemma 3.1, (repeating here for convenience)

$$
\partial_{t} \mu_{t}^{d}(x)=\mathcal{L}^{*} \mu_{t}^{d}(x)+\left(-\frac{r}{2} h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h(x)+(r-s) h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \frac{d Z_{t}^{d}}{d t}\right) \mu_{t}^{d}(x)
$$

and the Stratonovich form of (3.13),

$$
d q_{t}=\mathcal{L}^{*} q_{t}(x) d t-\frac{r}{2} h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h(x) q_{t}(x) d t+(r-s) q_{t}(x) h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \circ d Z_{t}
$$

We proceed with the following steps. The proof below is inspired by the proof of Theorem 3.1 in HKX02 except for the following important extensions: 1) we no longer assume $h$ is uniformly bounded; 2) $h$ is no longer a scalar valued function but may be vector valued; 3) we make use of the forward stochastic FeynmanKac style representation formula in Kun82 rather than the backward formula. Existence and uniqueness of density valued solutions to the zakai equation in $L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{m}\right)$ with $g, h$ unbounded has been studied by a number

of authors [BBH83; BKK95], building on extensive works in the unbounded case (see e.g. the excellent summary in [BC09]).

Step 1. Use (stochastic) Feynman-Kac type formulae to obtain a probabilistic representation of solutions to the Zakai equation and replicator-mutator equation, as given in Theorem A.1. Specifically, we make use of the formulae developed in [Kun82; Kun81] as was done in [HKX02] although we rely on the forward rather than backward representation formulae. Recall that $\mathcal{L}^{*}$ denotes the adjoint operator of the generator of the diffusion process

$$
d X_{t}=g\left(X_{t}\right) d t+\sigma\left(X_{t}\right) d W_{t}
$$

By expanding the adjoint operator, we may express it as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{L}^{*} \mu_{t}^{d}(x) & =-\sum_{i=1}^{m} \frac{\partial}{\partial x^{i}}\left(g^{i}(x) \mu_{t}^{d}(x)\right)+\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{m} \sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{i} \partial x^{j}}\left(\left(\sigma \sigma^{\top}\right)^{i j} \mu_{t}^{d}(x)\right) \\
& =-\sum_{i=1}^{m}\left(\mu_{t}^{d}(x) \frac{\partial g^{i}(x)}{\partial x^{i}}+g^{i}(x) \frac{\partial \mu_{t}^{d}(x)}{\partial x^{i}}\right)+\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{m} \sum_{j=1}^{m}\left(\mu_{t}^{d} \frac{\partial^{2}\left(\sigma \sigma^{\top}\right)^{i j}}{\partial x^{i} \partial x^{j}}+\left(\sigma \sigma^{\top}\right)^{i j} \frac{\partial^{2} \mu_{t}^{d}}{\partial x^{i} \partial x^{j}}\right) \\
& +\sum_{i=1}^{m} \frac{\partial \mu_{t}^{d}(x)}{\partial x^{i}} \sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{\partial\left(\sigma \sigma^{\top}\right)^{i j}}{\partial x^{j}} \\
& =\mathcal{G} \mu_{t}^{d}(x)+\left(-\sum_{i=1}^{m} \frac{\partial g^{i}(x)}{\partial x^{i}}+\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{m} \sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{\partial^{2}\left(\sigma \sigma^{\top}\right)^{i j}}{\partial x^{i} \partial x^{j}}\right) \cdot \mu_{t}^{d}(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

where in the second line we have used that $\sigma \sigma^{\top}$ is symmetric and $\mathcal{G}$ denotes the infinitesimal generator of the diffusion process

$$
d Y_{t}=\left(b\left(Y_{t}\right)-g\left(Y_{t}\right)\right) d t+\sigma\left(Y_{t}\right) d W_{t}^{y}
$$

where $W_{t}^{y}$ is a Wiener process independent of $W_{t}, b^{i}(x)=\nabla \cdot\left(\sigma(x) \sigma(x)^{\top}\right)^{i}$ and the superscript $i$ denotes the $i$ th row of the matrix $\sigma \sigma^{\top}$. That is,

$$
\mathcal{G} \mu_{t}^{d}(x):=-\sum_{i=1}^{m} g^{i}(x) \frac{\partial \mu_{t}^{d}(x)}{\partial x^{i}}+\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{m} \sum_{j=1}^{m}\left(\sigma \sigma^{\top}\right)^{i j} \frac{\partial^{2} \mu_{t}^{d}}{\partial x^{i} \partial x^{j}}+\sum_{i=1}^{m} \frac{\partial \mu_{t}^{d}(x)}{\partial x^{i}} \sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{\partial\left(\sigma \sigma^{\top}\right)^{i j}}{\partial x^{j}}
$$

This decomposition of $\mathcal{L}^{*}$ will be used in both (5.3) and (5.4); starting with (5.4) and using (1.4) yields,

$$
\begin{aligned}
d q_{t}(x)= & \mathcal{L}^{*} q_{t}(x)-\frac{r}{2} h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h(x) q_{t}(x)+(r-s) q_{t}(x) h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \circ d Z_{t} \\
= & \mathcal{G} q_{t}(x)+\left(-\sum_{i=1}^{m} \frac{\partial g^{i}(x)}{\partial x^{i}}+\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{m} \sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{\partial^{2}\left(\sigma \sigma^{\top}\right)^{i j}}{\partial x^{i} \partial x^{j}}-\frac{r}{2} h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h(x)+(r-s) h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\left(x_{t}^{*}\right) d t\right) \cdot q_{t}(x) \\
+ & (r-s) q_{t}(x) h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2} \circ d B_{t}
\end{aligned}
$$

This equation now takes the form of (1.1) in Theorem A. 1 with

$$
\begin{aligned}
t^{i k} & =0 \\
c^{k} & =(r-s)\left(h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k}, \quad k=1,2, \ldots, n \\
c^{0} & =-\sum_{i=1}^{m} \frac{\partial g^{i}(x)}{\partial x^{i}}+\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{m} \sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{\partial^{2}\left(\sigma \sigma^{\top}\right)^{i j}}{\partial x^{i} \partial x^{j}}-\frac{r}{2} h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h(x)+(r-s) h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\left(x_{t}^{*}\right) \\
a & =\sigma \\
b^{i} & =-g^{i}(x)+\sum_{j=1}^{m} \sum_{k=1}^{m} \sigma^{i k} \frac{\partial \sigma^{k j}}{\partial x^{j}}+\frac{1}{2} \sigma^{k j} \frac{\partial \sigma^{i k}}{\partial x^{j}}
\end{aligned}
$$

recalling that $x_{t}^{*}$ is treated as a fixed realisation. Then by Theorem A.1, there exists another probability space equipped with the measure $\mathbb{Q}$ (from here on we use the notation $\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}$ denote the expectation with respect to this measure) such that the solution can be represented as
$q_{t}(x)=\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[f\left(\xi_{t}(x)\right) \exp \left((r-s) \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \circ d Z_{u}-\frac{r}{2} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right) d u+\int_{0}^{t} \tilde{c}\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right) d u\right)\right]$
where $\xi_{s}(x)$ is a vector-valued function of $x$ denoting the solution of an SDE in the form of (1.2) in Theorem A. 1 with $b, a, l$ as defined above, i.e.

$$
d \xi_{t}(x)=\sum_{i=1}^{m} b^{i}\left(\xi_{t}(x)\right) d t+\sum_{j=1}^{m} \sum_{i=1}^{m} \sigma^{i j}\left(\xi_{t}(x)\right) \circ d W_{t}^{j}
$$

and $f(x)=\lim _{t \rightarrow 0} q_{t}(x)$ denotes the initial density and

$$
\tilde{c}(x):=-\sum_{i=1}^{m} \frac{\partial g^{i}(x)}{\partial x^{i}}+\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{m} \sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{\partial^{2}\left(\sigma(x) \sigma^{\top}(x)\right)^{i j}}{\partial x^{i} \partial x^{j}}
$$

We can similarly apply Theorem A. 1 to (5.3) with

$$
\begin{aligned}
c^{k} & =0 \\
c^{0} & =-\sum_{i=1}^{m} \frac{\partial g^{i}(x)}{\partial x^{i}}+\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{m} \sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{\partial^{2}\left(\sigma \sigma^{\top}\right)^{i j}}{\partial x^{i} \partial x^{j}}-\frac{r}{2} h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h(x)+(r-s) h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \frac{d Z_{t}^{d}}{d t}
\end{aligned}
$$

and $l, a, b$ as defined previously, to obtain the representation
$\mu_{t}^{d}(x)=\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[f\left(\xi_{t}(x)\right) \exp \left((r-s) \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \hat{Z}_{u}^{d} d u-\frac{r}{2} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right) d u+\int_{0}^{t} \tilde{c}\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right) d u\right)\right]$
where $\tilde{c}(x)$ is given in (5.7) and $\xi_{s}$ is as defined previously since $l^{i k}=0$ in both cases and from now onwards we use the shorthand notation $\hat{Z}_{t}^{d} \equiv \frac{d Z_{t}^{d}}{d t}$. Recall also that both (5.3) and (5.4) are assumed to be initialised by the same density $f(x)$.

Step 2. We are now ready to prove pointwise convergence using the above representation formulae. Firstly, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mu_{t}^{d}(x)-q_{t}(x) & =\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[f\left(\xi_{t}(x)\right) \exp \left(-\frac{r}{2} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right) d u+(r-s) \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \hat{Z}_{u}^{d} d u+\int_{0}^{t} \tilde{c}\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right) d u\right)\right] \\
& -\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[f\left(\xi_{t}(x)\right) \exp \left(-\frac{r}{2} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right) d u+(r-s) \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \circ d Z_{u}+\int_{0}^{t} \tilde{c}\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right) d u\right)\right] \\
& =: \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[f\left(\xi_{t}(x)\right) I_{2}(x) I_{1}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{2}(x) & =\exp \left(\int_{0}^{t} \tilde{c}\left(\xi_{s}(x)\right)-\frac{r}{2} h\left(\xi_{s}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\left(\xi_{s}(x)\right) d s\right) \\
I_{1}(x ; \mathcal{Z}) & =\exp \left((r-s) \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{s}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \hat{Z}_{s}^{d} d s\right)-\exp \left((r-s) \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{s}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \circ d Z_{s}\right) \\
& =: \exp \left(I_{3}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right)-\exp \left(I_{4}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and the $\mathcal{Z}$ notation is used to denote the dependence of $I_{1}$ on the observation path. In the below, let $\mathbb{E}$ refer to the expectation on the original space, i.e. wrt to the observation noise $W$. Then for any fixed $x \in \mathbb{R}^{m}$, in

other words, a realisation of the initialisation which has probability density $f(x)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\left|\mu_{t}^{d}(x)-q_{t}(x)\right|^{p}\right] & \leq \mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\left|f\left(\xi_{t}(x)\right) I_{2}(x) I_{1}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right|^{p}\right]\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\left|f\left(\xi_{t}(x)\right) I_{2}(x)\right|^{p} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|I_{1}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right|^{p}\right]\right] \quad \text { (Fubini) } \\
& \leq C\left(\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\left|f\left(\xi_{t}(x)\right) I_{2}(x)\right|^{p r_{2}}\right]\right)^{1 / r_{2}} \cdot\left(\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left|I_{1}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right|^{p}\right]\right)^{r_{1}}\right]\right)^{1 / r_{1}} \quad \text { (Hoelder inequality) } \\
& =: C I_{2}^{1 / r_{2}} \cdot I_{6}^{1 / r_{1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

for a constant $C>0$ independent of $t$ and with $1 / r_{1}+1 / r_{2}=1$ and $r_{1}, r_{2}>1$. Starting with $I_{2}$, since $g(x)$ is assumed to be $C^{2}$ and globally Lipschitz continuous and $\Sigma$ is a constant, it holds that $\tilde{c}(x)$ as defined in (5.7) is uniformly bounded. Additionally, it holds that $h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h(x)>0, \forall x \in \mathbb{R}^{m}$ since $\Xi$ is a positive definite matrix, so that there exists some $C_{2}>0$ independent of $t$. Combining, we have that

$$
\left|I_{2}(x)\right|^{p r_{2}}=\exp \left(p r_{2} \int_{0}^{t} \tilde{c}\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right) d u\right) \cdot \exp \left(-p r_{2} \frac{r}{2} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right) d u\right) \leq \exp \left(C_{1} t\right) \cdot C_{2}
$$

from which we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{5} & \leq \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\left|f\left(\xi_{t}(x)\right)\right|^{p r_{2}}\right] I_{2}(x)\left.\right|^{p r_{2}} ^{1} \\
& \leq C_{3}(t)
\end{aligned}
$$

using the fact that $f$ is uniformly bounded. Now turning to $I_{6}$, using the identity

$$
\begin{aligned}
|\exp (x)-\exp (y)|^{p} & \leq(\exp (x)+\exp (y))^{p}|x-y|^{p}, \quad x, y \in \mathbb{R} \\
& \leq C(\exp (p x)+\exp (p y))|x-y|^{p}
\end{aligned}
$$

along with Hoelder inequality yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{6} & \leq C \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\exp \left(p I_{3}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right)+\exp \left(p I_{4}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right)\right] I_{3}(x ; \mathcal{Z})-I_{4}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right|^{p}\right]\right)^{r_{1}}\right] \\
& \leq C \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(p I_{3}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right)\right] I_{3}(x ; \mathcal{Z})-I_{4}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right|^{p}\right]\right)^{r_{1}}+\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(p I_{4}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right] I_{3}(x ; \mathcal{Z})-I_{4}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right|^{p}\right]\right)^{r_{1}}\right] \\
& \leq C \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(r_{2} p I_{3}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right)\right]\right)^{r_{1} / r_{2}} \cdot \mathbb{E}\left[\left|I_{3}(x ; \mathcal{Z})-I_{4}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right|^{p r_{1}}\right]\right] \\
& +C \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(r_{2} p I_{4}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right)\right]\right)^{r_{1} / r_{2}} \cdot \mathbb{E}\left[\left|I_{3}(x ; \mathcal{Z})-I_{4}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right|^{p r_{1}}\right]\right] \\
& \leq C\left[\left(\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[I_{9}(x)^{r_{1}}\right]\right)^{1 / r_{2}}+\left(\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[I_{8}(x)^{r_{1}}\right]\right)^{1 / r_{2}}\right]\left(\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[I_{7}(x)^{r_{1}}\right]\right)^{1 / r_{1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
I_{7}(x):=\mathbb{E}\left[\left|I_{3}(x ; \mathcal{Z})-I_{4}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right|^{p r_{1}}\right], \quad I_{8}(x):=\mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(r_{2} p I_{4}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right)\right], \quad I_{9}(x):=\mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(r_{2} p I_{3}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right)\right]
$$

Step 3. The remainder of the proof will focus on showing that the terms involving $I_{8}$ and $I_{9}$ can be bounded by constants (depending on $t$ only). The term involving $I_{7}$ will the be shown to go to zero as $d \rightarrow \infty$, yielding

the desired convergence result. Starting with $I_{8}(x)$ and using the shorthand notation $p_{r}:=p(r-s)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(r_{2} p_{r} I_{4}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(r_{2} p_{r} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \circ d Z_{u}\right)\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(r_{2} p_{r} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right) d u+r_{2} p_{r} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2} d B_{u}\right)\right] \\
& \leq\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(r_{1} r_{2} p_{r} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right) d u\right)\right]\right)^{1 / r_{1}} \cdot\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(r_{2}^{2} p_{r} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2} d B_{u}\right)\right]\right)^{1 / r_{2}} \\
& \leq\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(r_{1} r_{2} p_{r} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right) d u\right)\right]\right)^{1 / r_{1}} \cdot\left(\prod_{k=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(n r_{2}^{2} p_{r} \int_{0}^{t}\left(h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k} d B_{u}^{k}\right)\right]\right)^{1 /\left(r_{2} n\right)} \\
& \leq\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(r_{1} r_{2} p_{r} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right) d u\right)\right]\right)^{1 / r_{1}} \cdot\left(\exp \left(\frac{n r_{2}^{2} p_{r}}{2} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \int_{0}^{t}\left(\left(h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k}\right)^{2} d u\right)\right)^{1 /\left(r_{2} n\right)} \\
& =\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(r_{1} r_{2} p_{r} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right) d u\right)\right]\right)^{1 / r_{1}} \cdot\left(\exp \left(\frac{n r_{2}^{2} p_{r}}{2} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right) d u\right)\right)^{1 /\left(r_{2} n\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

where in the last line, we have used Lemma (A.1) and the fact that $\xi_{s}$ is defined on a different probability space to the signal process. Then we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[I_{8}(x)^{r_{1}}\right]\right)^{1 / r_{2}} & \leq\left(\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(r_{1} r_{2} p_{r} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right) d u\right)\right] \cdot \exp \left(\frac{r_{1} r_{2} p_{r}}{2} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right) d u\right)\right]\right)^{1 / r_{2}} \\
& =\left(\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\exp \left(r_{1} r_{2} p_{r} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right) d u\right) \cdot \exp \left(\frac{r_{1} r_{2} p}{2} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right) d u\right)\right]\right)^{1 / r_{2}} \\
& =\left(\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\exp \left(r_{1} r_{2} p_{r} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1}\left(h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right)+\frac{1}{2} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)\right) d u\right)\right]\right)^{1 / r_{2}} \\
& =: I_{10}(x)^{1 / r_{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

since the expectation $\mathbb{E}$ is with respect to the observation noise and $x_{s}^{*}$ is taken as a fixed realisation.
To proceed further, we will make use of Lemma A. 4 which allows us to bound exponential moments of a non-decreasing process by its raw moments. Generally, it is not possible to bound exponential moments in terms of polynomial moments, as the exponential term grows faster. The crucial point of this lemma is in a careful specification of the factor in the exponential (c.f. $L$ in Lemma A.4) which acts to "dampen" the growth relative to the growth of the raw moments. We have using the shorthand notation $\tilde{L}:=\frac{r_{1} r_{2} p_{r}}{2}$,

$$
I_{10}(x) \leq \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\exp \left(\tilde{L} \int_{0}^{t} \tilde{h}_{u}\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \tilde{h}_{u}\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right) d u\right)\right]
$$

where $\tilde{h}_{u}(y):=h(y)+h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right)$. Furthermore,

$$
\tilde{h}_{u}(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \tilde{h}_{u}(x)=\left|\Xi^{-1 / 2} \tilde{h}_{u}(x)\right|^{2} \leq \lambda_{\Xi}^{2}\left|\tilde{h}_{u}(x)\right|^{2}, \quad \forall x \in \mathbb{R}^{m}
$$

where $\lambda_{\Xi}$ is the smallest eigenvalue of $\Xi^{1 / 2}$. Combining, we have letting $L=\tilde{L} \lambda_{\Xi}^{2}$,

$$
I_{10}(x) \leq \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\exp \left(L \int_{0}^{t}\left|\tilde{h}_{u}\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)\right|^{2} d u\right)\right]
$$

Let $Y_{t}(x):=\int_{0}^{t}\left|\tilde{h}_{u}\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)\right|^{2} d u$. Clearly this is a non-decreasing (and adapted) process, so that we may apply lemma A.4. In particular,

$$
\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[Y_{t}(x)-Y_{\tau}(x)\right]=\int_{\tau}^{t} \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\left|\tilde{h}_{u}\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)\right|^{2}\right] d u \leq t C\left(1+\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[|x|^{2}\right]\right)=: K(t), \quad \forall \tau \in[0, t)
$$

where $C$ is a constant depending on the growth properties of $h$ and for the last inequality, we have used that since $g, h$ satisfy lipschitz and linear growth assumptions,

$$
\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\left|\tilde{h}_{u}\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)\right|^{2}\right] \leq C\left(1+\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\left|\xi_{u}(x)\right|^{2}\right]\right) \leq C\left(1+\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[|x|^{2}\right]\right)
$$

Therefore by Lemma A.4, whenever

$$
\frac{r_{1} r_{2}(r-s) p \lambda_{S}^{2}}{2}<\frac{1}{K(t)}
$$

where $K(t)$ is a constant depending on time, the second moment of the initial density $f(x)$ and the linear growth constant of $h$, we have

$$
I_{10}(x) \leq \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\exp \left(L \int_{0}^{t}\left|\tilde{h}_{s}\left(\xi_{s}(x)\right)\right|^{2} d s\right)\right]<\frac{1}{1-L K(t)}
$$

Notice that condition (5.9) can be satisfied whenver $r, s$ are chosen such that $(r-s)$ is small enough. As will be seen in Section 4.2, this is at least possible in the linear-Gaussian setting whilst maintaining optimality (in the mean squared error sense) even in the case of a misspecified model. Finally, we have

$$
\left(\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[I_{8}(x)^{r_{1}}\right]\right)^{1 / r_{2}} \leq(1-L K(t))^{-\frac{1}{r_{2}}}
$$

The term involving $I_{9}(x)$ can be analysed in much the same way as for $I_{8}(x)$, with the only difference being that the stochastic integral. In particular, we have letting $j$ refer to the index such that $t \in\left(t_{j}, t_{j+1}\right]$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(r_{2} p_{r} I_{3}(x ; \mathcal{Z})\right)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(r_{2} p_{r} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \hat{Z}_{u}^{d} d u\right)\right] \\
& \leq\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(r_{1} r_{2} p_{r} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right) d u\right)\right]\right)^{1 / r_{1}} \cdot\left(\prod_{k=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(n r_{2}^{2} p_{r} \int_{0}^{t}\left(h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k} \dot{B}_{u}^{k} d u\right)\right]\right)^{1 /\left(r_{2} n\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

where with a slight abuse of notation, we let $\dot{B}_{t} \equiv \dot{B}_{t}^{d}$ and $\dot{B}_{t}^{k}$ denotes the $k$ th component of $\dot{B}_{t}$. Furthermore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(n r_{2}^{2} p_{r} \int_{0}^{t}\left(h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k} \dot{B}_{r}^{k} d \tau\right)\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(n r_{2}^{2} p_{r} \sum_{i=1}^{j} \frac{1}{\delta_{d}} \int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}}\left(\int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}}\left(h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k} d u\right) d B_{\tau}^{k}+n r_{2}^{2} p_{r} \int_{t_{j}}^{t}\left(h\left(\xi_{s}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k} \dot{B}_{\tau}^{k} d \tau\right)\right] \\
& =\prod_{i=1}^{j} \mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(n r_{2}^{2} p_{r} \frac{1}{\delta_{d}}\left(\int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}}\left(h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k} d u\right) \int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}} d B_{\tau}^{k}\right)\right] \mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(n r_{2}^{2} p_{r}\left(\int_{t_{j}}^{t}\left(h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k} d u\right) \int_{t_{j}}^{t_{j+1}} d B_{\tau}^{k}\right)\right] \\
& \leq \prod_{i=1}^{j} \exp \left(\frac{n r_{2}^{2} p_{r}}{2} \int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}}\left(h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k} d u\right) \cdot \exp \left(\frac{n r_{2}^{2} p_{r}}{2} \int_{t_{j}}^{t}\left(h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k} d u\right) \\
& =\exp \left(\frac{n r_{2}^{2} p_{r}}{2} \int_{0}^{t}\left(h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k} d u\right) \\
& \leq \exp \left(\frac{n r_{2}^{2} p_{r}}{2} \int_{0}^{t}\left|\left(h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k}\right|^{2} d u\right) \\
& \leq \exp \left(\frac{n r_{2}^{2} p_{r}}{2} \int_{0}^{t}\left|\left(h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k}\right|^{2} d u\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the second equality holds due to independence of brownian increments and in the first inequality holds due to lemma A.1. Combining this result with the same calculations as for $I_{8}$ yields an upper bound on $I_{9}$ which is identical to (5.8). Therefore, following the same reasoning as in for $I_{8}$, we have

$$
\left(\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[I_{9}(x)^{r_{1}}\right]\right)^{1 / r_{2}} \leq(1-L K(t))^{-\frac{1}{r_{2}}}
$$

Finally, for $I_{7}$, first note that for $t \in\left[t_{j}, t_{j+1}\right)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \hat{Z}_{u}^{d} d u & =\sum_{i=1}^{j} \int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1}\left(h\left(x_{t_{i-1}}^{*}\right)+\frac{1}{\delta_{d}} \Xi^{1 / 2}\left(B_{t_{i}}-B_{t_{i-1}}\right)\right) d u \\
& +\int_{t_{j}}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1}\left(h\left(x_{t_{j}}^{*}\right)+\frac{1}{\delta_{d}} \Xi^{1 / 2}\left(B_{t_{j+1}}-B_{t_{j}}\right)\right) d u
\end{aligned}
$$

similarly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \circ d Z_{u} & =\int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} d Z_{u} \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{j} \int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1}\left(h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right) d u+\Xi^{1 / 2} d B_{u}\right)+\int_{t_{j}}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1}\left(h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right) d u+\Xi^{1 / 2} d B_{u}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|I_{3}-I_{4}\right|^{p r_{1}} \leq|2(r-s)|^{p r_{1}}\left(\left|\sum_{i=1}^{j} \int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1}\left(h\left(x_{t_{i-1}}^{*}\right)-h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right)\right) d u+\int_{t_{j}}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1}\left(h\left(x_{t_{j}}^{*}\right)-h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right)\right) d u\right|^{p r_{1}} \\
& +\left|\int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2} \hat{B}_{u}^{d} d u-\int_{0}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2} d B_{u}\right|^{p r_{1}^{2}}\right) \\
& =:|2(r-s)|^{p r_{1}}\left(I_{11}+I_{12}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

As we are required to upper bound $\mathbb{E}\left[\left|I_{3}-I_{4}\right|^{p r_{1}}\right]$, we obtain the following bound for $\mathbb{E}\left[I_{12}\right]$ following the same reasoning as in pg 41 of [HKX02] (bound on $I_{5}^{\mathrm{II}}(x)$ in their proof),

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[I_{12}\right] & =\mathbb{E}\left[\left|\sum_{k=1}^{n} \int_{0}^{t}\left(h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k} \hat{B}_{u}^{k} d u-\int_{0}^{t}\left(h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k} d B_{u}^{k}\right|^{p r_{1}}\right] \\
& \leq n^{p r_{1}} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|\int_{0}^{t}\left(h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k} \hat{B}_{u}^{k} d u-\int_{0}^{t}\left(h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k} d B_{u}^{k}\right|^{p r_{1}}\right] \\
& \leq C \frac{1}{\delta_{d}} \sum_{i=1}^{j} \int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}} \int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(h\left(\xi_{u}(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k}-\left(h\left(\xi_{\tau}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k}\right|^{p r_{1}}\right] d \tau d u \\
& +C \delta_{d}^{\frac{p r_{1}}{2}-1} \int_{t_{j}}^{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(h\left(\xi_{\tau}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k}\right|^{p r_{1}}\right] d \tau
\end{aligned}
$$

where $C$ is a constant depending on $n$. It is worthwhile clarifing that classical Wong-Zakai/piecewise smooth convergence results are focused on stochastic integrals of the form $\left|\int h\left(X_{s}\right) \circ d B_{s}-\int h\left(X_{s}^{d}\right) \hat{B}_{s}^{d} d s\right|$ where the integrand $X_{s}^{d}$ is dependent on $B_{s}^{d}$. As the coefficient here $h\left(\xi_{s}(x)\right.$ evolves independently of $B$, we can resort to simpler convergence tools than used in e.g. [Pat24]. Starting with the second term, we have under the assumptions on $b, g, h$ using lemma A.3,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(h\left(\xi_{\tau}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k}\right]^{p r_{1}} \mid & \leq \mathbb{E}\left[\left(h\left(\xi_{\tau}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k}-\left(h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k}\right]^{p r_{1}}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\left(h(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k}\right]^{p r_{1}} \mid \\
& \leq C(x)|\tau|^{p r_{1} / 2}+C(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
C \delta_{d}^{\frac{p r_{1}}{2}-1} \int_{t_{j}}^{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(h\left(\xi_{\tau}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k}\right]^{p r_{1}} \mid d \tau & \leq C \delta_{d}^{\frac{p r_{1}}{2}-1} C(x) \int_{t_{j}}^{t}\left(|\tau|^{p r_{1} / 2}+1\right) d \tau \\
& \leq C \delta_{d}^{\frac{p r_{1}}{2}-1} C(x)\left(\delta_{d}^{p r_{1} / 2+1}+\delta_{d}\right) \\
& \leq C(x) \delta_{d}^{p r_{1} / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then for the first term on the rhs of the inequality, making use of lemma A. 3 and that $h$ is lipschitz continuous and at most linear growth, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& C \frac{1}{\delta_{d}} \sum_{i=1}^{j} \int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}} \int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|(h\left(\xi_{u}(x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k}-\left(h\left(\xi_{\tau}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2}\right)^{k}\right|^{p r_{1}}\right] d \tau d u \\
& \leq C(x) \frac{1}{\delta_{d}} \sum_{i=1}^{j} \int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}} \int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}}|\tau-u|^{p r_{1} / 2} d \tau d u \\
& =\leq C(x) \frac{1}{\delta_{d}} \sum_{i=1}^{j} \delta^{p r_{1} / 2} \int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}} \int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}} d \tau d u \\
& \leq C(x) \frac{1}{\delta_{d}} \sum_{i=1}^{j} \delta^{p r_{1} / 2+2} \\
& =C(x) \frac{1}{\delta_{d}} \frac{t_{j}}{\delta_{d}} \delta^{p r_{1} / 2+2}=C(x) \delta_{d}^{p r_{1} / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Combining the two yields

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[I_{12}(x)\right] \leq C(x) \delta_{d}^{p r_{1} / 2}
$$

Finally, for $I_{11}(x)$ we have using the notation $\left\lfloor x_{t}^{*}\right\rfloor=x_{t_{i}}^{*}, t \in\left[t_{i-1}, t_{i}\right]$ and Lemma A. 3 and the linear growth assumption on $h$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[I_{11}(x)\right] & =\mathbb{E}\left[\left|\int_{0}^{t_{j}} h\left(\xi_{s}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1}\left(h\left(\left\lfloor x_{u}^{*}\right\rfloor\right)-h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right)\right) d u+\int_{t_{j}}^{t} h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1}\left(h\left(x_{t_{j}}^{*}\right)-h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right)\right) d u\right|^{p r_{1}}\right] \\
& \leq C \int_{0}^{t_{j}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1}\left(h\left(\left\lfloor x_{u}^{*}\right\rfloor\right)-h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right)\right)\right|^{p r_{1}}\right] d u+C \int_{t_{j}}^{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|h\left(\xi_{u}(x)\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1}\left(h\left(x_{t_{j}}^{*}\right)-h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right)\right)\right|^{p r_{1}}\right] d u \\
& \leq n^{p r_{1}} C\left(1+C_{h}(x)\right) \sum_{i=1}^{j} \int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|h\left(x_{t_{i-1}}^{*}\right)-h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right)\right|^{p r_{1}}\right] d u+\int_{t_{j}}^{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|h\left(x_{t_{j}}^{*}\right)-h\left(x_{u}^{*}\right)\right|^{p r_{1}}\right] d u \\
& \leq n^{p r_{1}} C\left(1+C_{h}(x)\right) \sum_{i=1}^{j+1} \int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}} \delta_{d}^{p r_{1} / 2} d u \\
& \leq n^{p r_{1}} C\left(1+C_{h}(x)\right) \frac{t_{j+1}}{\delta_{d}} \delta_{d}^{p r_{1} / 2+1} \\
& \leq n^{p r_{1}} C(t)\left(1+C_{h}(x)\right) \delta_{d}^{p r_{1} / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

We are now ready to bound the remaining term involving $I_{7}$, i.e.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[I_{7}(x)^{r_{1}}\right]\right)^{1 / r_{1}} & \leq(2(r-s))^{p}\left(\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\left(\mathbb{E}\left[I_{11}(x)\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[I_{12}(x)\right]\right)^{r_{1}}\right]\right)^{1 / r_{1}} \\
& \leq C(r-s)^{p}\left(\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[C(x)^{r_{1}}\right] \delta_{d}^{p r_{1}^{2} / 2}\right)^{1 / r_{1}} \\
& \leq C(r-s)^{p} \delta_{d}^{p r_{1} / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

under the assumption of finite $p>1$ moments of the initial density $f(x)$. Choosing $r_{1}>1$ large enough for a given $p$ gives us the required decay as $\delta_{d} \rightarrow 0$.

# 5.4 Proof of Lemma 4.1 

Proof. We start with the proof of the first claim for the Stochastic EnKbf. Note that (4.10) takes the form

$$
d \bar{X}_{t}=G \bar{X}_{t} d t+\mu_{t}\left(\bar{X}_{t}\right) d t+\Sigma^{1 / 2} d W_{t}+\sigma_{t} d \bar{B}_{t}+\sigma_{t}^{*} d Z_{t}
$$

with

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma_{t} & =\sqrt{2(r-s)} C_{t} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2} \\
\mu_{t}(x) & =-\frac{s}{2} C_{t} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H\left(x-m_{t}\right)-(r-s) C_{t} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H x \\
\sigma_{t}^{*} & =(r-s) C_{t} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

and denote by $D_{t}:=\frac{1}{2} \sigma \sigma^{\top}$. The (observation conditioned) forward Kolmogorov equation (see e.g. [PRS21]) is then given by

$$
\partial_{t} \rho_{t}(x)=\mathcal{L}^{*} \rho_{t}(x) \underbrace{-\nabla \cdot\left(\rho_{t}(x) \mu_{t}(x)\right)-\nabla \rho_{t}(x) \cdot \sigma_{t}^{z} d Z_{t}+\nabla \cdot\left(D_{t} \nabla \rho_{t}(x)\right)}_{=: \mathcal{M}^{*} \rho_{t}(x)}
$$

where

$$
\mathcal{L}^{*} \rho_{t}(x)=-\nabla \cdot\left(\rho_{t}(x) G x\right)+\nabla \cdot\left(\Sigma \nabla \rho_{t}(x)\right)
$$

characterises the evolution under the signal process. The remaining term can be simplified further using that $\rho_{t}(x)=\mathcal{N}\left(x ; m_{t}, C_{t}\right) \forall t \geq 0$ with $m_{t}, C_{t}$ to be determined,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{M}^{*} \rho_{t}(x) & =\rho_{t}(x) \operatorname{Tr}\left[\left(x-m_{t}\right)^{\top} C_{t}^{-1} D_{t} C_{t}^{-1}\left(x-m_{t}\right)-D_{t} C_{t}^{-1}+\left(x-m_{t}\right)^{\top} C_{t}^{-1} \mu_{t}(x)\right]-\rho_{t}(x) \nabla \cdot \mu_{t}(x) \\
& +\left(x-m_{t}\right)^{\top} C_{t}^{-1} \rho_{t}(x) \sigma_{t}^{z} d Z_{t} \\
& =\rho_{t}(x) \frac{s}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left[H^{\top} C_{t} H \Xi^{-1}\right]+(r-s)\left(H x-H m_{t}\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} d Z_{t} \rho_{t}(x) \\
& -\frac{s}{2} \rho_{t}(x)\left(H x-H m_{t}\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1}\left(H x-H m_{t}\right)-(r-s) \rho_{t}(x)\left(x-m_{t}\right)^{\top} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H m_{t}
\end{aligned}
$$

using the cyclic property of the trace. Substituting back into (5.10) yields an equation formally an equation formally equivalent to (4.1) since

$$
\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\left\|H x-H m_{t}\right\| \frac{2}{2}\right]=\operatorname{Tr}\left[H^{\top} C_{t} H \Xi^{-1}\right]
$$

The proof of the second claim follows from a similar line of reasoning with $\sigma_{t}=0$ and $\mu_{t}(x)=\left(\frac{r}{2}-s\right) C_{t} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H(x-$ $\left.m_{t}\right)-\frac{(r-s)}{2} C_{t} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H\left(x+m_{t}\right)$ and is therefore omitted.

The claim involving the deterministic update and piecewise smooth observation (4.12) follows form a very similar line of reasoning. Nevertheless, we provide it here for completeness. Note that (4.12) can be written in the form,

$$
d \bar{X}_{t}=G \bar{X}_{t} d t+\mu_{t}\left(\bar{X}_{t}\right) d t+\Sigma^{1 / 2} d W_{t}
$$

with

$$
\mu_{t}(x)=-\left(\frac{s}{2}+\frac{(r-s)}{2}\right) C_{t} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H x+(r-s) C_{t} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \frac{d Z_{t}^{d}}{d t}+\left(\frac{s}{2}-\frac{r-s}{2}\right) C_{t} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H m_{t}
$$

The (conditional) forward Kolmgorov equation is then given by

$$
\partial_{t} \rho_{t}(x)=\mathcal{L}^{*} \rho_{t}(x) \underbrace{-\nabla \cdot\left(\rho_{t}(x) \mu_{t}(x)\right)}_{=: \mathcal{M}^{*} \rho_{t}}
$$

where $\mathcal{L}^{*}$ is as given in (5.11). We have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{M}^{*} \rho_{t}(x) & =\rho_{t}(x) \operatorname{Tr}\left[\left(x-m_{t}\right)^{\top} C_{t}^{-1} \mu_{t}(x)\right]-\rho_{t}(x) \nabla \cdot \mu_{t}(x) \\
& =\left(\frac{s}{2}+\frac{(r-s)}{2}\right) \rho_{t}(x) \mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\left\|H x-H m_{t}\right\| \frac{2}{5}\right]-\left(\frac{s}{2}+\frac{(r-s)}{2}\right)\left(H x-H m_{t}\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H x \rho_{t}(x) \\
& +\left(\left(\frac{s}{2}-\frac{r-s}{2}\right) C_{t} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H m_{t}\right)^{\top} C_{t}^{-1}\left(x-m_{t}\right) \rho_{t}(x)+(r-s)\left(H x-H m_{t}\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \frac{d Z_{t}^{d}}{d t} \rho_{t}(x) \\
& =(r-s) \rho_{t}(x)\left(-\frac{1}{2} x^{\top} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H x+\left(H x-H m_{t}\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \frac{d Z_{t}^{d}}{d t}\right)-\frac{s}{2} \rho_{t}(x)\left(x^{\top} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H x-\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\left\|H x-H m_{t}\right\| \frac{2}{5}\right]\right) \\
& -\frac{(r-s)}{2} \mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\left\|H x-H m_{t}\right\| \frac{2}{5}\right]+\left(\frac{s}{2}+\frac{(r-s)}{2}\right)\left(H m_{t}\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H x \rho_{t}(x) \\
& +\left(\left(\frac{s}{2}-\frac{r-s}{2}\right) C_{t} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H m_{t}\right)^{\top} C_{t}^{-1}\left(x-m_{t}\right) \rho_{t}(x) \\
& =(r-s) \rho_{t}(x)\left(-\frac{1}{2} x^{\top} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H x+\left(H x-H m_{t}\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \frac{d Z_{t}^{d}}{d t}\right)-\frac{s}{2} \rho_{t}(x)\left(x^{\top} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H x-\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[\left\|H x-H m_{t}\right\| \frac{2}{5}\right]\right) \\
& -\frac{(r-s)}{2} \mathbb{E}_{p_{t}^{d}}\left[x^{\top} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H x\right] \rho_{t}(x)+s \rho_{t}(x)(H x)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H m_{t}-\frac{s}{2} \rho_{t}(x)\left(H m_{t}\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H m_{t}
\end{aligned}
$$

once again using that

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}\left[\left\|H x-H m_{t}\right\| \frac{2}{5}\right]=\operatorname{Tr}\left[H^{\top} C_{t} \Xi^{-1} H\right]
$$

Substituting back into (5.12) yields an equation formally equivalent to (4.2).
For the proof of the final claim, i.e. for stochastic update with piecewise smooth observations $\left\{Z_{t}^{d}\right\}$, note that (4.13) takes the form

$$
d \bar{X}_{t}=G \bar{X}_{t} d t+\mu_{t}\left(\bar{X}_{t}\right) d t+\Sigma^{1 / 2} d W_{t}+\sigma_{t} d \bar{B}_{t}
$$

with

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma_{t} & =\sqrt{r-s} C_{t} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1 / 2} \\
\mu_{t}(x) & =-\frac{s}{2} C_{t} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H\left(x-m_{t}\right)+(r-s) C_{t} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1}\left(\frac{d Z_{t}^{d}}{d t}-H x\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and denote by $D_{t}:=\frac{1}{2} \sigma_{t} \sigma_{t}^{\top}$. The (conditional) forward Kolmgorov equation is then given by

$$
\partial_{t} \rho_{t}(x)=\mathcal{L}^{*} \rho_{t}(x) \underbrace{-\nabla \cdot\left(\rho_{t}(x) \mu_{t}(x)\right)+\nabla \cdot\left(D_{t} \nabla \rho_{t}(x)\right)}_{=: \mathcal{M}^{*} \rho_{t}(x)}
$$

where $\mathcal{L}^{*}$ is as given in (5.11). The remaining term can be simplified further using that $\rho_{t}(x)=\mathcal{N}\left(x ; m_{t}, C_{t}\right) \forall t \geq$ 0 with $m_{t}, C_{t}$ to be determined,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{M}^{*} \rho_{t}(x) & =\rho_{t}(x) \operatorname{Tr}\left[\left(x-m_{t}\right)^{\top} C_{t}^{-1} D_{t} C_{t}^{-1}\left(x-m_{t}\right)-D_{t} C_{t}^{-1}+\left(x-m_{t}\right)^{\top} C_{t}^{-1} \mu_{t}(x)\right]-\rho_{t}(x) \nabla \cdot \mu_{t}(x) \\
& =\rho_{t}(x) \frac{r}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left[H^{\top} C_{t} \Xi^{-1} H\right]+(r-s)\left(H x-H m_{t}\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \frac{d Z_{t}^{d}}{d t} \rho_{t}(x) \\
& +\left(\frac{r}{2}-s\right) \rho_{t}(x)\left(H x-H m_{t}\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1}\left(H x-H m_{t}\right)-(r-s) \rho_{t}(x)\left(x-m_{t}\right)^{\top} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H x \\
& =(r-s)\left(H x-H m_{t}\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1} \frac{d Z_{t}^{d}}{d t} \rho_{t}(x)-\frac{(r-s)}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left[H x \Xi^{-1}(H x)^{\top}-\mathbb{E}_{p_{t}}\left[H x \Xi^{-1}(H x)^{\top}\right]\right] \rho_{t}(x) \\
& -\frac{s}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left[\left(H x-H m_{t}\right)^{\top} \Xi^{-1}\left(H x-H m_{t}\right)-H^{\top} C_{t} \Xi^{-1} H\right] \rho_{t}(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

using the cyclic property of the trace and the identity

$$
\operatorname{Tr}\left[\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}\left[x x^{\top}\right]-x x^{\top}\right]=\operatorname{Tr}\left[\left(x-m_{t}\right)\left(x-m_{t}\right)^{\top}-2 x\left(x-m_{t}\right)^{\top}+C_{t}\right]
$$

Inserting back into (5.13) yields a formal equivalence to (4.2), as desired.

# 5.5 Proof of Lemma 4.4 

Proof. Starting from the evolution equation for the mean (4.3), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
d \varepsilon_{t} & =d m_{t}-d X_{t}^{*} \\
& =\left(G-(r-s) K_{t} H\right) \varepsilon_{t} d t-b d t+\Sigma^{1 / 2} d W_{t}+(r-s) K_{t} \Xi^{1 / 2} d B_{t}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $x_{t}^{*}$ denotes the reference process that generated the observation path, from which we obtain the evolution of the expected error

$$
d \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}\right]=\left(G-(r-s) K_{t} H\right) \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}\right] d t-b d t
$$

Also,

$$
\begin{aligned}
d \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}\right] \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}^{\top}\right] & =\mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}\right] d \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}^{\top}\right]+d \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}\right] \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}^{\top}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}\right] \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}^{\top}\right]\left(G-(r-s) K_{t} H\right)^{\top} d t+\left(G-(r-s) K_{t} H\right) \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}\right] \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}^{\top}\right] d t-\mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}\right] b^{\top} d t-b \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}^{\top}\right] d t
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\tilde{P}_{t}=\mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t} \varepsilon_{t}^{\top}\right]$ and using Ito formula, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
d \tilde{P}_{t} & =\mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}\left(d \varepsilon_{t}\right)^{\top}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\left(d \varepsilon_{t}\right) \varepsilon_{t}^{\top}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[d \varepsilon_{t}\left(d \varepsilon_{t}\right)^{\top}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t} \varepsilon_{t}^{\top}\left(G-(r-s) K_{t} H\right)^{\top} d t-\varepsilon_{t} b^{\top} d t\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\left(G-(r-s) K_{t} H\right) \varepsilon_{t} \varepsilon_{t}^{\top} d t-b \varepsilon_{t}^{\top} d t\right]+\Sigma d t+(r-s)^{2} K_{t} \Xi K_{t}^{\top} d t \\
& =\tilde{P}_{t}\left(G-(r-s) K_{t} H\right)^{\top} d t+\left(G-(r-s) K_{t} H\right) \tilde{P}_{t} d t-\mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}\right] b^{\top} d t-b \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}^{\top}\right] d t+\Sigma d t+(r-s)^{2} K_{t} \Xi K_{t}^{\top} d t
\end{aligned}
$$

which yields (4.23). Using, $P_{t}=\tilde{P}_{t}-\mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}\right] \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}^{\top}\right]$ and combining the above expressions yields (4.22) and (4.23).

For the second claim, consider that when $s=0$, we have

$$
d P_{t}=\left(G-r K_{t} H\right) P_{t} d t+P_{t}\left(G-r K_{t} H\right)^{\top} d t+\Sigma d t+r^{2} K_{t} \Xi K_{t}^{\top} d t
$$

whose solution at any given time $t$ is formally equivalent to $C_{t}$ (whose time evolution is given by 4.4) if $P_{0}=C_{0}$ and $r=1$, since $K_{t} \Xi K_{t}^{\top}=K_{t} H C_{t}$. Notice that due to the $r^{2} K_{t} \Xi K_{t}^{\top}$ rather than $r K_{t} \Xi K_{t}^{\top}$ term, this equivalence only holds when $r=1$ in addition to $s=0$.

For the final claim, since $\operatorname{Tr}\left(\tilde{P}_{t}\right)=E_{t}$, using the cyclic property of the trace yields

$$
\frac{d \operatorname{Tr}\left(\tilde{P}_{t}\right)}{d t}=\operatorname{Tr}\left[\left(A_{t}+A_{t}^{\top}\right) \tilde{P}_{t}\right]-2 \operatorname{Tr}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}\right] b^{\top}\right]+\operatorname{Tr}[\Sigma]+(r-s)^{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left[K_{t} \Xi K_{t}^{\top}\right]
$$

where $A_{t}(r, s):=G-(r-s) K_{t} H$ and we have used the cyclic property of the trace. Then using $\operatorname{Tr}[A B] \leq$ $\alpha(A) \operatorname{Tr}[B]$ for any real symmetric matrix $A$ and p.d. matrix $B$, where $\alpha(A)$ denotes the largest eigenvalue of real matrix $A$, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\operatorname{Tr}\left[\left(A_{t}+A_{t}^{\top}\right) P_{t}\right] \leq \alpha\left(A_{t}+A_{t}^{\top}\right) \operatorname{Tr}\left[\tilde{P}_{t}\right] \\
\operatorname{Tr}\left[K_{t} \Xi K_{t}^{\top}\right]=\operatorname{Tr}\left[H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H C_{t}^{\top} C_{t}\right] \leq \alpha\left(H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H\right)\left\|C_{t}\right\|_{F}
\end{gathered}
$$

where $\|A\|_{F}=\operatorname{Tr}\left[A^{\top} A\right]$ is the Frobenius norm. Substituting into (5.16) yields (4.24).

### 5.6 Proof of Lemma 4.5

Proof. Under assumption 4.2, $C_{\infty}$ exists and is unique (see e.g. [BD23]). When $C_{0}=C_{\infty}$ we have that $K_{t}=K_{\infty}=C_{\infty} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1}$ for all $t \geq 0$. Using (5.17) and the shorthand notation $A_{\infty}(r, s):=G-(r-s) K_{\infty} H$,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}\right]=\exp \left(t A_{\infty}(s, r)\right) \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{0}\right]+A_{\infty}^{-1}(s, r)\left[I-\exp \left(t A_{\infty}(s, r)\right)\right] b
$$

When $\alpha\left(A_{\infty}(r, s)\right)<0$, for a given $r, s$, it holds that as $t \rightarrow \infty, \quad \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}\right] \rightarrow-A_{\infty}(r, s)^{-1} b$, from which we obtain (4.26).

For brevity, we drop the dependence on $r, s$ in $A_{\infty}(r, s)$ in the remainder of the proof. For the second claim, rewrite (4.23) as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d \tilde{P}_{t}}{d t} & =A_{\infty} \tilde{P}_{t}+\tilde{P}_{t} A_{\infty}^{\top}+\mathcal{B}_{t} \\
\mathcal{B}_{t} & :=\Sigma+(r-s)^{2} K_{\infty} \Xi K_{\infty}^{\top}-\mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}\right] b^{\top}-b \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{t}^{\top}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

which has explicit solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
\tilde{P}_{t} & =\exp \left(t A_{\infty}\right) \tilde{P}_{0} \exp \left(t A_{\infty}^{\top}\right)+\int_{0}^{t} \exp \left((t-u) A_{\infty}\right)\left(\Sigma+(r-s)^{2} K_{\infty} \Xi K_{\infty}^{\top}\right) \exp \left((t-u) A_{\infty}^{\top}\right) \mathrm{d} u \\
& -\int_{0}^{t} \exp \left((t-u) A_{\infty}\right)\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{u}\right] b^{\top}+b \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{u}^{\top}\right]\right) \exp \left((t-u) A_{\infty}^{\top}\right) \mathrm{d} u
\end{aligned}
$$

The final term can be simplified further, using (5.17) and the assumption $\mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{0}\right]=0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -\int_{0}^{t} \exp \left((t-u) A_{\infty}\right) \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{u}\right] b^{\top} \exp \left((t-u) A_{\infty}^{\top}\right) \mathrm{d} u \\
& =-\int_{0}^{t} \exp \left((t-u) A_{\infty}\right) A_{\infty}^{-1} b b^{\top} \exp \left((t-u) A_{\infty}^{\top}\right) \mathrm{d} u+\exp \left(t A_{\infty}\right) A_{\infty}^{-1} b b^{\top} \int_{0}^{t} \exp \left((t-u) A_{\infty}^{\top}\right) \mathrm{d} u
\end{aligned}
$$

and the remaining term involving $b \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{u}^{\top}\right]$ is the transpose of the above. Evaluating the last integral in the above and substituting into (5.18) and taking trace of both sides yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Tr}\left[\tilde{P}_{t}\right] & =\operatorname{Tr}\left[\exp \left(t A_{\infty}\right) \tilde{P}_{0} \exp \left(t A_{\infty}^{\top}\right)\right]+2 \operatorname{Tr}\left[\exp \left(t A_{\infty}\right) A_{\infty}^{-1} b b^{\top} \exp \left(t A_{\infty}^{\top}\right)\left(I-\exp \left(-t A_{\infty}^{\top}\right)\right)\left(A_{\infty}^{-1}\right)^{\top}\right] \\
& +\int_{0}^{t} \operatorname{Tr}\left[\exp \left((t-u) A_{\infty}\right) \tilde{\Sigma} \exp \left((t-u) A_{\infty}^{\top}\right)\right] \mathrm{d} u
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\tilde{\Sigma}:=\Sigma+(r-s)^{2} K_{\infty} \Xi K_{\infty}^{\top}-A_{\infty}^{-1} b b^{\top}-b b^{\top}\left(A_{\infty}^{-1}\right)^{\top}$. It holds that the all terms except for the integral term in (5.19) go to zero as $t \rightarrow \infty$ when $\alpha\left(A_{\infty}\right)<0$. For the integral term, by the cyclic property of the trace,

$$
\int_{0}^{t} \operatorname{Tr}\left[\exp \left((t-u) A_{\infty}\right) \tilde{\Sigma} \exp \left((t-u) A_{\infty}^{\top}\right)\right] \mathrm{d} u=\operatorname{Tr}\left[\tilde{\Sigma} \int_{0}^{t} \exp \left(v A_{\infty}\right) \exp \left(v A_{\infty}^{\top} d v\right)\right]
$$

Furthermore, when $\alpha\left(A_{\infty}\right)<0$,

$$
\int_{0}^{\infty} \exp \left(v A_{\infty}\right) \exp \left(v A_{\infty}^{\top}\right) d v=X_{\infty}
$$

where $X_{\infty}$ is a symmetric matrix that is the unique solution of the Lyapunov equation

$$
A_{\infty}^{\top} X_{\infty}+X_{\infty} A_{\infty}+I=0
$$

Combining yields the result (4.27).
For the upper bound on $E_{\infty}$, consider the differential inequality in (4.24), recall (and using assumption $\left.\mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{0}\right]=0\right)$,

$$
\frac{d E_{t}}{d t} \leq \alpha\left(A_{\infty}+A_{\infty}^{\top}\right) E_{t}+\beta_{t}+\gamma
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\beta_{t} & :=2 \operatorname{Tr}\left[A_{\infty}^{-1} \exp \left(t A_{\infty}\right) b b^{\top}\right] \\
\gamma & :=-2 \operatorname{Tr}\left[A_{\infty}^{-1} b b^{\top}\right]+\operatorname{Tr}[\Sigma]+(r-s)^{2} \lambda_{\max }\left(H^{\top} \Xi^{-1} H\right)\left\|C_{\infty}\right\|_{F}
\end{aligned}
$$

By Gronwall lemma,

$$
E_{t} \leq e^{\alpha\left(A_{\infty}+A_{\infty}^{\top}\right) t}\left[E_{0}+\int_{0}^{t} \beta_{s} e^{-\alpha\left(A_{\infty}+A_{\infty}^{\top}\right s} d s\right]+\frac{\gamma}{\alpha\left(A_{\infty}+A_{\infty}^{\top}\right)}\left(e^{\alpha\left(A_{\infty}+A_{\infty}^{\top}\right) t}-1\right)
$$

using the cyclic property of the trace,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{t} \operatorname{Tr}\left[A_{\infty}^{-1} \exp \left(s A_{\infty}\right) b b^{\top}\right] e^{-\alpha\left(A_{\infty}+A_{\infty}^{\top}\right) s} d s & =\operatorname{Tr}\left[b b^{\top} A_{\infty}^{-1} \int_{0}^{t} \exp \left(s A_{\infty}\right) e^{-\alpha\left(A_{\infty}+A_{\infty}^{\top}\right) s} d s\right] \\
& =\operatorname{Tr}\left[b b^{\top} A_{\infty}^{-1}\left(A_{\infty}-\alpha\left(A_{\infty}+A_{\infty}^{\top}\right) I\right)^{-1}\left(\exp \left(t\left(A_{\infty}-\alpha\left(A_{\infty}+A_{\infty}^{\top}\right) I\right)\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where the final equality holds since $A_{\infty}-\alpha\left(A_{\infty}+A_{\infty}^{\top}\right) I$ is invertible. Combining yields

$$
E_{t} \leq e^{\alpha\left(A_{\infty}+A_{\infty}^{\top}\right) t} E_{0}+2 \operatorname{Tr}\left[b b^{\top} A_{\infty}^{-1}\left(A_{\infty}-\alpha\left(A_{\infty}+A_{\infty}^{\top}\right) I\right)^{-1} \exp \left(t A_{\infty}\right)\right]+\frac{\gamma}{\alpha\left(A_{\infty}+A_{\infty}^{\top}\right)}\left(e^{\alpha\left(A_{\infty}+A_{\infty}^{\top}\right) t}-1\right)
$$

Taking the limit $t \rightarrow \infty$ yields the result (4.28) due to assumptions 4.2 and 4.3 .
For the final claim, in the scalar case $m=n=1$, (4.25) is explicitly solvable with

$$
C_{\infty}=\frac{G+\sqrt{G^{2}+r H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}}{r H^{2} \Xi^{-1}}
$$

which when substituted into $K_{\infty}=C_{\infty} H \Sigma^{-1}$ yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
A_{\infty} & =G-\frac{(r-s)}{r}\left(G+\sqrt{G^{2}+r H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}\right) \\
& =\frac{s}{r} G-\frac{(r-s)}{r} \sqrt{G^{2}+r H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}
\end{aligned}
$$

We can also trivially solve the Lyapunov equation (5.21) to obtain

$$
X_{\infty}=-\frac{1}{2} A_{\infty}^{-1}
$$

Substituting the above expressions into (4.27) yields (4.30).

# 5.7 Proof of Lemma 4.6 

Proof. In the below we drop the $(s, r)$ dependency in $A_{\infty}(s, r)$ where there is no ambiguity. Recall also that in the scalar case $E_{t}=\hat{P}_{t}$, and we will use the notation $\hat{P}_{\infty}$ in the below to refer to the asymptotic MSE.

We start with the proof of the first claim, i.e. the optimal $s$ for any given $r>0$ minimising (4.30) by solving

$$
\frac{\partial \hat{P}_{\infty}}{\partial s}=\frac{\partial \hat{P}_{\infty}}{\partial A_{\infty}} \frac{\partial A_{\infty}}{\partial s}=0
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\partial \hat{P}_{\infty}}{\partial A_{\infty}}=-2 b^{2} A_{\infty}^{-3}+A_{\infty}^{-1}\left(\frac{G-A_{\infty}}{H}\right) \frac{\Xi}{H}+\frac{1}{2} A_{\infty}^{-2}\left(\Sigma+\left(\frac{G-A_{\infty}}{H}\right)^{2} \Xi\right) \\
& \frac{\partial A_{\infty}}{\partial s}=\frac{G}{r}+\frac{\sqrt{G^{2}+r H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}}{r}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\frac{\partial A_{\infty}}{\partial s}$ is clearly never zero, we need only solve

$$
g\left(A_{\infty}\right):=A_{\infty}^{3}-\frac{\left(H^{2} \Sigma+\Xi G^{2}\right)}{\Xi} A_{\infty}+\frac{4 b^{2} H^{2}}{\Xi}=0
$$

which takes the form of a depressed cubic $A_{\infty}^{3}+p A_{\infty}+q=0$ with $p=-\left(H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma+G^{2}\right), q=4 b^{2} H^{2} \Xi^{-1}$, and we have that $q>0, p<0$ always. The nature of the roots can be characterised in the usual way via the discriminant $\tau$, i.e. when $\tau>0$, (5.24) has one real root and two complex roots, whilst when $\tau<0$, it has three real roots. We deal with these two cases below separately.

Case 1: $\tau>0$. First we show that the real root here is strictly negative. From inspection, we have that $g(0)>0$. Also, (5.24) always has two real extremal (turning) points, one of which is strictly negative and the other is strictly positive, since $g^{\prime}\left(A_{\infty}\right)=3 A_{\infty}^{2}+p=0$ implies the extremal points occur at $A_{\infty}= \pm \sqrt{\frac{-p}{3}}$. Furthermore, $g^{\prime}(0)=p<0$. Combining these properties implies that (5.24) has one negative real root when $\tau>0$. When $\tau>0$, we can use Cardano's formula to obtain an expression for the real root,

$$
A_{\infty}^{*}=\left(-\frac{q}{2}+\sqrt{\tau}\right)^{1 / 3}+\left(-\frac{q}{2}-\sqrt{\tau}\right)^{1 / 3}
$$

from which we then obtain (4.34), and substituting the expression for $A_{\infty}^{*}$ into (4.31) and re-arranging yields (4.33). It can be verified straightforwardly that this this is indeed a minimum since $\frac{\partial^{2} \tilde{P}_{\infty}}{\partial A_{\infty}^{*}}\left(A_{\infty}^{*}\right)>0$.

Case 2: $\tau<0$. In this case, (5.24) has three real roots due to the usual condition on the discriminant. First we characterise the signs of the roots. We have directly from (5.24) that $g(0)>0$. Also, (5.24) always has two real extremal (turning) points, one of which is strictly negative and the other is strictly positive, since $g^{\prime}\left(A_{\infty}\right)=3 A_{\infty}^{2}+p=0$ implies the extremal points occur at $A_{\infty}= \pm \sqrt{\frac{-p}{3}}$. Furthermore, $g^{\prime}(0)=p<0$. Combining these properties implies that (5.24) has two positive real roots and one negative real root when $\tau<0$.

When $\tau<0$, the following trigonometric formula holds for the characterisation of the three real roots, $A_{\infty}^{k}, k=0,1,2$

$$
A_{\infty}^{k}=2 \sqrt{-\frac{p}{3}} \cos \left[\frac{1}{3} \cos ^{-1}\left(\frac{3 q}{2 p} \sqrt{\frac{-3}{p}}\right)-\frac{2 \pi k}{3}\right] \quad \text { for } k=0,1,2
$$

To determine the negative root, first notice that $-\frac{2 \pi k}{3}<\frac{1}{3} \cos ^{-1}(y)-\frac{2 \pi k}{3}<-\frac{2 \pi k}{3}+\frac{\pi}{3}$ for all $-1<y<1$. Furthermore, $\cos (\theta)<0$ for all $-\frac{3 \pi}{2}<\theta<-\frac{\pi}{2}$ and it holds that for $\theta:=\frac{1}{3} \cos ^{-1}(y)-\frac{2 \pi k}{3}$ and $k=2$, $-\frac{4}{3} \pi<\theta<-\pi$, so that $\cos (\theta)<0$ for $k=2$. This yields the remaining case in (4.34).

For the remaining claims, we work with the following change of variable

$$
y:=\sqrt{G^{2}+r H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}
$$

which when substituted into (4.33) with $r=\frac{y^{2}-G^{2}}{H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}$ yields

$$
s^{\mathrm{opt}}(y)=\frac{1}{H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}(y-G)\left(A_{\infty}^{*}+y\right)
$$

We may now characterise the admissible values of $s$ for a fixed $r$. Since we require $A_{\infty}<0$ to ensure the existence of $\tilde{P}_{\infty}$, any choice of $s$ must satisfy

$$
\frac{s}{r} G-\frac{(r-s)}{r} \sqrt{G^{2}+r H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}<0
$$

from which the upper bound in (4.35) immediately follows (along with the requirement that $s<r$ ). The minimiser of $s^{\text {opt }}(y)$ wrt $y$, which we donne by $y^{*}$, can be found straightforwardly by solving $\frac{d s^{\text {opt }}(y)}{d y}=0$, giving

$$
y^{*}=\frac{G-A_{\infty}^{*}}{2}
$$

which implies that for any $r>0$,

$$
s^{\mathrm{opt}} \geq-\frac{\left(G+A_{\infty}^{*}\right)^{2}}{4 H^{2} \Xi \Sigma}=: s^{l}
$$

since $y$ is monotonically related to $r$ (notice also that $s^{l}$ is independent of $r$ ). Note however that by definition, $y>|G|$ since $r>0$. Therefore the lower bound on admissible $s$ values corresponds to $s^{l}$ if $G-2|G|<A_{\infty}^{*}$, otherwise it corresponds to $s^{\text {opt }}(y=|G|)$, which we denote by $s^{u}$ in the lemma.

Finally, we can obtain expressions for $r^{\text {opt }}$ for a given $s$ satisfying the aforementioned constraints by a straightforward rearrangement of (5.28),

$$
y^{2}+\left(A_{\infty}^{*}-G\right) y-G A_{\infty}^{*}-s H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma=0
$$

yielding

$$
y=\frac{\left(G-A_{\infty}^{*}\right) \pm \sqrt{\left(G-A_{\infty}^{*}\right)^{2}+4\left(G A_{\infty}^{*}+s H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma\right)}}{2}
$$

Note that $s^{\text {opt }}(y)$ is a convex quadratic in $y$, with roots $y=G$ and $y=-A_{\infty}^{*}$ and minimum attained at $y=y^{*}$ as defined in (5.27). Also, it holds that $y>|G|$ which follows directly from the definition (5.25) and that $r>0$. Therefore, whenever $y^{*}<|G|$, there is a unique admissible $y$ value for any given $s$ satisfying the aforementioned constraints. More specifically, this value is given by

$$
y=\frac{\left(G-A_{\infty}^{*}\right)+\sqrt{\left(G-A_{\infty}^{*}\right)^{2}+4\left(G A_{\infty}^{*}+s H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma\right)}}{2}
$$

Finally, whenever $y^{*} \geq|G|$, there are two admissible $y$ values for any given $s^{l}<s<s^{\text {opt }}(y=|G|)$, and a unique $y$ value for $s>s^{\text {opt }}(y=|G|)$ given by (5.31). Substituting the definition of $y$ into the above expressions for $y$ and rearranging yields the expressions for $r^{\text {opt }}$. The final claim is now proved.

# 5.8 Proof of Lemma 4.7 

Proof. The first claim follows from a simple re-arrangement of the identity $C_{\infty}=\tilde{P}_{\infty}$ with $A_{\infty}=A_{\infty}^{*}$, i.e.

$$
-\frac{1}{2}\left(\Sigma+\left(\frac{G-A_{\infty}^{*}}{H}\right)^{2} \Xi\right) \frac{1}{A_{\infty}^{*}}+\left(\frac{b}{A_{\infty}^{*}}\right)^{2}=\frac{G+\sqrt{G^{2}+r H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}}{r H^{2} \Xi^{-1}}
$$

additionally, rearranging (5.23) yields

$$
G+\sqrt{G^{2}+r H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}=\frac{r\left(G-A_{\infty}^{*}\right)}{(r-s)}
$$

substituting into the expression for $\tilde{P}_{\infty}=C_{\infty}$ yields the result. Additionally, we have

$$
r=\frac{1}{4 H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}\left(G-A_{\infty}^{*} \pm \sqrt{\left(G-A_{\infty}^{*}\right)^{2}+4\left(G A_{\infty}^{*}+s H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma\right)}\right)^{2}-\frac{G^{2}}{H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}
$$

so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
r-s & =\frac{1}{4 H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}\left(G-A_{\infty}^{*} \pm \sqrt{\left(G-A_{\infty}^{*}\right)^{2}+4\left(G A_{\infty}^{*}+s H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma\right)}\right)^{2}-\frac{G^{2}}{H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}-s \\
& =\frac{\left(A_{\infty}^{*}\right)^{2}\left(G-A_{\infty}^{*}\right)}{-0.5 A_{\infty}^{*}\left(H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma+\left(G-A_{\infty}^{*}\right)^{2}\right)+b^{2} H^{2} \Xi^{-1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

For the claim (4.40), when $s=0$, it follows directly from (4.33) that

$$
r_{0}^{\mathrm{opt}}=\frac{\left(A_{\infty}^{*}\right)^{2}-G^{2}}{H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}
$$

First establish the following bound on $A_{\infty}^{*}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
A_{\infty}^{*} & =\left(-\frac{q}{2}+\sqrt{\tau}\right)^{1 / 3}+\left(-\frac{q}{2}-\sqrt{\tau}\right)^{1 / 3} \\
& <\left(-\frac{q}{2}+\sqrt{\frac{q^{2}}{4}+\frac{p^{3}}{27}}\right)^{1 / 3}+\left(-\frac{q}{2}-\sqrt{\tau}\right)^{1 / 3} \\
& <\left(-\left(-\frac{p^{3}}{27}\right)^{1 / 2}+\sqrt{\frac{q^{2}}{4}+\frac{p^{3}}{27}}\right)^{1 / 3}+\left(-\frac{q}{2}-\sqrt{\tau}\right)^{1 / 3} \\
& <\left(-\left(-\frac{p^{3}}{27}\right)^{1 / 2}\right)^{1 / 3}+\left(-\frac{q}{2}-\sqrt{\tau}\right)^{1 / 3}
\end{aligned}
$$

recalling that $p=-\left(H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma+G^{2}\right), q=4 b^{2} H^{2} \Xi^{-1}$. The condition $\tau>0$ also implies

$$
-\frac{q}{2}<-\left(-\frac{p^{3}}{27}\right)^{1 / 2}
$$

Then using the inequality $\sqrt{2}\left(a_{1}+a_{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \geq \sqrt{a_{1}}+\sqrt{a_{2}}$,

$$
-\frac{q}{2}-\sqrt{\tau}<-\frac{q}{2}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\frac{q}{2}+\left|\frac{p^{3}}{27}\right|^{1 / 2}\right)=-\frac{\sqrt{2}+1}{\sqrt{2}} \frac{q}{2}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left|\frac{p^{3}}{27}\right|^{1 / 2}<-\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}+2}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\left|\frac{p^{3}}{27}\right|^{1 / 2}
$$

Putting altogether, we have

$$
A_{\infty}^{*}<-\frac{2 \sqrt{2}+2}{\sqrt{6}} \sqrt{|p|}
$$

Then letting $c:=\frac{2 \sqrt{2}+2}{\sqrt{6}}$ and substituting into (5.32) yields

$$
\left(A_{\infty}^{*}\right)^{2}>c^{2}\left(H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma+G^{2}\right)
$$

and

$$
r_{0}^{\mathrm{opt}}>\frac{\left(c^{2}-1\right) G^{2}+c^{2} H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}{H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}>\frac{\left(c^{2}-1\right)\left(G^{2}+H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma\right)}{H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}>1
$$

since $c^{2}>1$, which yields (4.40). Then for the remainder of the claim, we have (using $r$ in place of $r_{0}^{\text {opt }}$ for brevity),

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{C_{\infty}}{\tilde{C}_{\infty}} & =\frac{1}{r}\left(\frac{G+\sqrt{G^{2}+r H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}}{G+\sqrt{G^{2}+H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}}\right) \\
& \leq \frac{1}{r}\left(\frac{2|G|+\sqrt{r H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}}{G+\sqrt{G^{2}+H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}}\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{r} \frac{2|G|}{\left(G+\sqrt{G^{2}+H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}\right)}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{r}} \frac{\sqrt{H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}}{\left(G+\sqrt{G^{2}+H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}\right)} \\
& \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{r}}\left(\frac{2|G|+\sqrt{H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}}{\left(G+\sqrt{G^{2}+H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}\right)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

whenever $r>1$. Furthermore, when $G>0$ we have that

$$
\frac{2 G+\sqrt{H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}}{G+\sqrt{G^{2}+H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}} \leq \sqrt{2}
$$

Finally, due to (4.40)

$$
\frac{1}{\sqrt{r}} \leq \frac{\sqrt{H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}}{\sqrt{2} \sqrt{G^{2}+H^{2} \Xi^{-1} \Sigma}}<\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}
$$

Multiplying the two inequalities yields the final claim (4.41).

# 6 Conclusion 

We presented a detailed investigation of connections between continuous time, continuous trait Crow-Kimura replicator-mutator dynamics [Kim65] and the fundamental equation of non-linear filtering, the KushnerStratonovich partial differential equation. Inspired by a non-local fitness functional presented in the mathematical biology literature [CHR06], we extended this connection to obtain a "modified" Kushner-Stratonovich equation. This equation was shown to beneficial for filtering with misspecified models and a specific choice of parameters in the fitness functional was shown to coincide with covariance inflated Kalman Bucy filtering, in the linear-Gaussian setting. Additionally, we considered the misspecified model filtering problem, with linear-Gaussian dynamics and where the misspecification arises through an unknown constant bias in the signal dynamics. We proved that through a judicious choice of parameters in the fitness functional, mean squared error and uncertainty quantification (through the covariance) could be improved via this modified Kushner-Stratonovich equation. Estimation is improved over traditional covariance inflation techniques, as well as over the standard filtering setup (assuming perfect model knowledge).

There are several avenues for further work, most notably, the analysis on misspecified models in Section 4 has primarily focused on the scalar setting which has simplified the analysis. In future works, the multivariate setting, as well as extensions to nonlinear dynamics should be explored. Additionally, it would be worthwhile to extend the mode of convergence in Theorem 3.1 to $L^{p}$ convergence rather than pointwise convergence.

## A Technical lemmata

Theorem A.1. Forward representation formula (Theorem 3.1 in [Kun82].) Let $u_{t}(x, \omega)$ for $t \in[0, T]$, $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ denote a measurable stochastic process on a probability space $(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P})$ with $\omega \in \Omega$ (from now on we suppress the $\omega$ notation). Suppose its time evolution is given by

$$
\partial_{t} u_{t}(x)=\mathcal{L} u_{t}(x)+\sum_{k=1}^{n} \mathcal{M}^{k} u_{t}(x) \circ d B_{t}^{k}, \quad u_{0}(x)=f(x)
$$

where $B_{t}^{k}$ is a Brownian motion wrt $\mathbb{P}$ and $f$ a bounded $C^{2}$ function with bounded derivatives and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{L} & :=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{j=1}^{m}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{m} a^{i j}(x) \frac{\partial}{\partial x^{i}}\right)^{2}+\sum_{i=1}^{m} b^{i}(x) \frac{\partial}{\partial x^{i}}+c^{0} \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{m} \sum_{j=1}^{m}\left(\sum_{k} a^{i k} a^{j k}\right) \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{i} \partial x^{j}}+\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i, j} a^{i j} \sum_{k}\left(\frac{\partial a^{k j}}{\partial x^{i}}\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial x^{k}}+\sum_{i=1}^{m} b^{i}(x) \frac{\partial}{\partial x^{i}}+c^{0} \\
\mathcal{M}^{k} & :=\sum_{i=1}^{m} l^{i k}(x) \frac{\partial}{\partial x^{i}}+c^{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

with $c^{k}(x)$ being uniformly bounded $C^{2}$ functions with bounded derivatives in $x$ and $a^{i j}(x), b^{i}(x), m^{i k}(x)$ being uniformly bounded $C^{4}$ functions with bounded first derivatives in $x$.

Then there exists another probability space $(\bar{\Omega}, \mathcal{B}, \mathbb{Q})$ on which the Brownian motion $W_{t}=\left[W_{t}^{1}, \ldots, W_{t}^{m}\right]^{\top}$ is defined and an SDE on the product space $(\Omega \otimes \bar{\Omega}, \mathcal{F} \otimes \mathcal{B}, \mathbb{P} \otimes \mathbb{Q})$ given by

$$
d \xi_{t}(x)=\sum_{i=1}^{d} b^{i}\left(\xi_{t}(x)\right) d t+\sum_{j=1}^{m} \sum_{i=1}^{m} a^{i j}\left(\xi_{t}(x)\right) \circ d W_{t}^{j}+\sum_{k=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{m} l^{i k}\left(\xi_{t}(x)\right) \frac{\partial \xi_{t}(x)}{\partial x^{i}} \circ d B_{t}^{k}
$$

where the notation $\xi_{t}(x)$ is used to denote the solution of the SDE with initial condition $\xi_{0}=x$ and $t>0$. The solution of (1.1) has the representation

$$
u_{t}(x)=\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[f\left(\xi_{t}(x)\right) \exp \left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} \int_{0}^{t} c^{k}\left(\xi_{s}(x)\right) \circ d B_{s}^{k}+\int_{0}^{t} c^{0}\left(\xi_{s}(x)\right) d s\right)\right], \quad x \in \mathbb{R}^{m}
$$

The following form of Ito-Stratonovich correction will also be useful. Consider the following Stratonovich SDE

$$
d \xi_{t}=X_{0}\left(t, \xi_{t}\right) d t+\sum_{j=1}^{m} X_{j}\left(t, \xi_{t}\right) \circ d W_{t}^{j}
$$

where $X_{j}$ is a Lipschitz cts function with derivatives in the second argument up to second order. Let $\xi_{0, r}(x)$ denote the solution of the above Stratonovich SDE at time $r$ with initial condition $\xi_{0}=x$. Then the following relation between the Ito and Stratonovich integral holds (backward form!)

$$
\int_{s}^{t} X^{k}\left(f\left(\xi_{r, t}(x)\right) \circ d B_{r}^{k}=\int_{s}^{t} X^{k}\left(f\left(\xi_{r, t}(x)\right)\right) d W_{r}^{k}+\frac{1}{2} \int_{s}^{t}\left(X^{k}\left(f\left(\xi_{r, t}(x)\right)\right)\right)^{2} d r\right.
$$

where $f: \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is a $C^{3}$ function.
Some well-known results from stochastic analysis are presented below.

Lemma A.1. Moment generating function. Consider

$$
Y_{t}=\int_{0}^{t} \vartheta_{s} d W_{s}
$$

where $\vartheta_{s}$ is a deterministic, scalar-valued continuous function of $s$ and $W_{t}$ is a real-valued Brownian motion wrt a probability measure $\mathbb{P}$. Then

$$
\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{P}}\left[\exp \left(\lambda Y_{t}\right)\right]=\exp \left(\frac{\lambda}{2} \int_{0}^{t} \vartheta_{s}^{2} d s\right)
$$

Lemma A.2. Consider a probability space $(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P})$ on which a scalar valued Wiener process is defined. Suppose $f(s, \omega)$ for $\omega \in \Omega$ is an $\mathcal{F}_{t}$-adapted process. Then the following inequality holds for $q>1$

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left|\int_{0}^{t} f(s, \omega) d W_{s}\right|^{2 q}\right] \leq t^{q-1}(q(2 q-1))^{q} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{t}|f(s, \omega)|^{2 q} d s\right]
$$

The following well-known lemma will also be used
Lemma A.3. Continuity of solutions of SDEs Let $g, \sigma$ be lipschitz continuous functions satisfying linear growth conditions. Denote by $\xi_{t}(x)$ the unique solution to

$$
d \xi_{t}=g\left(\xi_{s}\right) d s+\sigma\left(\xi_{s}\right) d B_{s}
$$

with $\xi_{0}=x$. Suppose $h$ is a globally lipschitz continuous real vector valued function. Then it holds that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left|h\left(\xi_{s}(x)\right)-h\left(\xi_{r}(x)\right)\right|^{q}\right] \leq C(x)|s-r|^{q / 2}
$$

Lemma A.4. Exponential moment bounds. Let $Y_{s}$ for $s \in[0, t]$ denote a non-decreasing scalar-valued adapted process such that $\mathbb{E}\left[Y_{t}-Y_{s} \mid \mathcal{F}_{s}\right] \leq K$ for all $s \in[0, t]$. Then for any $L<\frac{1}{K}$,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(L Y_{t}\right)\right]<\frac{1}{1-L K}
$$

Lemma A.5. Unbiasedness of the non-local replicator-mutator with perfect system. Consider the signal-observation pair (1.3)-(1.4) with $g(x)=G x, h(x)=H x$ and Gaussian initial conditions. If $m_{0}=\mathbb{E}\left[X_{0}\right]$ then the generalised Kalman-Bucy filter with $s<r, r>0$ is unbiased, i.e. $\mathbb{E}\left[m_{t}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[X_{t}\right], t>0$.

Proof. Begin with the mean equation from the generalised Kalman-Bucy filter

$$
\begin{aligned}
m_{t} & =m_{0}+\int_{0}^{t} G m_{u} d u+(r-s) \int_{0}^{t} K_{u} d Z_{u}-(r-s) \int_{0}^{t} K_{u} H m_{u} d u \\
& =m_{0}+\int_{0}^{t} G m_{u} d u+(r-s) \int_{0}^{t} K_{u} H\left(X_{u}^{*}-m_{u}\right) d u+(r-s) \int_{0}^{t} K_{u} \Xi^{1 / 2} d B_{u}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $K_{t}:=C_{t} H^{\top} \Xi^{-1}$ corresponds to the Kalman gain at time $t$ and we have substituted in the form of the observations in the second equality. Then

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[m_{t}\right]=m_{0}+\int_{0}^{t} G \mathbb{E}\left[m_{u}\right] d u+(r-s) \int_{0}^{t} K_{u} H\left(\mathbb{E}\left[X_{u}^{*}\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[m_{u}\right]\right) d u
$$

Also recall that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[X_{t}^{*}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[X_{0}^{*}\right]+\int_{0}^{t} G \mathbb{E}\left[X_{u}^{*}\right] d u
$$

then

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[m_{t}\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[X_{t}^{*}\right]=m_{0}-\mathbb{E}\left[X_{0}^{*}\right]+\int_{0}^{t}\left(G-(r-s) K_{s} H\right)\left(\mathbb{E}\left[m_{s}\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[X_{s}^{*}\right]\right) d s
$$

which corresponds to an ODE of the form $\dot{y}_{t}=A_{t} y_{t}$ with $y_{t}:=\mathbb{E}\left[m_{t}\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[X_{t}^{*}\right]$, which has solutions $y_{t}=$ $0, t>0$ whenever $y_{0}=0$.

abstract:
It has long been posited that there is a connection between the dynamical
equations describing evolutionary processes in biology and sequential Bayesian
learning methods. This manuscript describes new research in which this precise
connection is rigorously established in the continuous time setting. Here we
focus on a partial differential equation known as the Kushner-Stratonovich
equation describing the evolution of the posterior density in time. Of
particular importance is a piecewise smooth approximation of the observation
path from which the discrete time filtering equations, which are shown to
converge to a Stratonovich interpretation of the Kushner-Stratonovich equation.
This smooth formulation will then be used to draw precise connections between
nonlinear stochastic filtering and replicator-mutator dynamics. Additionally,
gradient flow formulations will be investigated as well as a form of
replicator-mutator dynamics which is shown to be beneficial for the
misspecified model filtering problem. It is hoped this work will spur further
research into exchanges between sequential learning and evolutionary biology
and to inspire new algorithms in filtering and sampling.
